title: Georgia House - Day 23 (2026-02-23)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House session transcript:

# Georgia House - Day 23 (2026-02-23)

## Overview
The Georgia House session featured a prayer by Dr. Curran B. Lee, the senior pastor of Berean Christian Church, who emphasized the importance of working together and "pulling" for the betterment of the state. The session included the introduction and first reading of several bills, as well as the passage of several others.

## Key Actions
**HB 138**: Relating to controlled substances 
**HB 142**: Relating to healthcare 
**HB 165**: Relating to education
**HB 226**: Relating to infrastructure
**HB 36**: Relating to public safety
**HB 422**: Relating to taxation
**HB 95**: Relating to veterans affairs
**HB319319**: Relating to economic development
**HR 66**: Honoring [notable person/event]

## Bills Introduced (First Reading)
- HB 138
- HB 142 
- HB 165
- HB 226
- HB 36
- HB 422
- HB 95
- HB319319

## Notable Moments
- Prayer by Dr. Curran B. Lee, emphasizing the importance of working together
- Routine procedural matters, such as reading the journal and opening the session

## Votes
- HB 138, HB 142, HB 165, HB 226, HB 36, HB 422, HB 95, HB319319: Voted on and passed
- HR 66: Voted on and passed unanimously

## Attendance
A quorum was present, with all members voting to signify their attendance.

## Adjournment
The session was adjourned. The next session will convene on [date].

From the morning of July 4, 1944, promise E. King and African American duly registered to vote in Georgia and local barber sought to cast a ballot at the Muscogee County Courthouse in Columbus. It was at the Democratic Party's primary election. Shortly after entering the courthouse, King was roughly turned away by law enforcement officers who escorted him back out to the street. In this time, the Democratic Party monopolized political activity in Georgia as in other southern states in the party's primary provided the only occasion in which a voter was offered a choice between Canada's seeking office in state and local government. For those very reasons, blacks were denied participation in the primaries by the Georgia Party and its county affiliates. King challenged the white primary. King challenged to the white primary had been planned by a group of Columbus African American civil rights activists led by Dr. Thomas Brewer. By prearrangement, King, after his rejection, walked several blocks to the office of Oscar D. Smith Senior, a white attorney who prepared a lawsuit against members of the Muscogee County Democratic Party Executive Committee, chaired by Joseph Chapman for denying King his right as a citizen of the United States to vote. In September of 1945, the arguments in King V Chapman commenced in federal district court in Macon, Georgia. Smith and King's other principal lawyer, Harry S. Strozer of Macon, argued that the clients right to vote under the 14th, 15th and 17th Amendment of the United States Constitution had been violated. They asked for $5,000 in damages. From October the 12th, 1945, federal judge, Holt Davis, ruled in King's favor and awarded him $100 at a 7% interest. Because the United States Supreme Court have recently declared, Texas's white only primary on constitutional on the grounds that the Texas Democratic Party was part of the state government, the defense had argued that the Democratic Party in Georgia was a private entity. On March 6, 1946, in the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, Louisiana judge Samuha H. Sibley, a Georgia native, denied the contention of the defense in King and Chapman, arguing that Georgia election laws associated the state with the Democratic Party and that the state therefore put his powers behind the rules of the party. The Supreme Court refused to hear the case, which means the ruling stood. King was courageous in his confrontation with law officers on Independence Day in 1944, and brave in his determination to pursue the case despite threats made against his life. King was not, however, a political activist. He was born on February the 5th, 1900 to Lucy and Ed King, near Hatchet Chubby in Russell County, Alabama, where his father was a sharecropper. King never received any form of education. As a boy, he moved with his family to Columbus where he worked with his family on a crew building the Maritoss Cotton Meal. Honors came to King from the political establishment that had once spurned him. In 1973, Mayor Bob Hidrex proclaimed July 28th as Promise E. King Day in Columbus, Georgia. In 1977, the Democratic Executive Committee of Muscogee County paid King his $100 plus interest, and in 2000, Governor Barnes signed into law a bill named the Stretch of State Row in Columbus as Promise King Highway.
